qas.question: What used to be considered an art, back in the day?
What could an accomplished tailor or seamstress skillfully render almost invisible?
Why did it make sense to spend time fixing cloth?
What type of person is likely to replace zippers and buttons?
What is still considered an art today?
A mediocre tail or seamstress could make it so what?
When cloth was worth less than the labor it made sense to do what?
What is not considered a consumable item today?
What is more expensive than the labor required to repair it?

context: In past times, <a0_0><b5_0>mending<b5_0/><a0_0/> was an art. A meticulous tailor or seamstress could mend rips with thread raveled from hems and seam edges so skillfully that <b6_0>the <a1_0>tear<a1_0/> was practically invisible<b6_0/>. When the raw material – <b8_0>cloth<b8_0/> – was <a2_0>worth more than labor<a2_0/>, it made sense to <b7_0>expend labor in saving it<b7_0/>. Today clothing is considered <a3_0>a consumable item<a3_0/>. <b9_0>Mass-manufactured clothing<b9_0/> is less expensive than the labor required to repair it. Many people buy a new piece of clothing rather than spend time mending. The <a4_0>thrifty<a4_0/> still replace zippers and buttons and sew up ripped hems.
